docs.lead_paragraph: The recent plea agreement with a former senior Enron trader presents new opportunities for the law enforcement officials investigating a range of possible crimes at the company. But it also creates challenges for prosecutors that did not exist before. Under the agreement announced last week, the trader, Timothy N. Belden, pleaded guilty to conspiring with others to manipulate the California energy market during the state's energy crises that began in 2000, and he agreed to cooperate in the investigation of Enron. In his statements to the court, Mr. Belden acknowledged submitting false commitments for energy delivery for the purpose of driving up prices.
docs.abstract: Recent plea agreement with former senior Enron trader Timothy N Belden presents new opportunities for law enforcement officials investigating range of possible crimes at company; he admits to conspiring with others to manipulate California energy market during its 2000 crisis and acting to force up prices; higher Enron management may be implicated; certain former admissions Belden made might leave his testimony open to attack by defense counsel (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation has agreed to pay nearly $30 million in additional severance to about 4,200 former employees who were laid off after the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last December. The company said today that after long negotiations it had reached a tentative agreement with the largest creditors in the bankruptcy case and a group of former employees who had been pressing the company for a larger severance package.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp agrees to pay nearly $30 million in additional severance to about 4,200 former employees who were laid off after company filed bankruptcy protection last December; Enron will pay former employees up to $7,900 in additional severance; many former employees have already received as much as $5,600 in severance pay (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After the disaster, I got back to Houston as quickly as possible and at first could hardly tell anything had happened. It was not as if a bomb had exploded or a building had collapsed. There had been a disappearance, that is all, and the effect was not apparent until I got out of the car. It was the fear I noticed, and I saw it first when I sat down with Elyse Lanier. Lanier is the wife of the former mayor and the closest thing the fourth-largest city in the country has to a mother. In her enormous diamonds and green leather pants, she ate a hamburger and fries and spoke of ''the setbacks we've had'' -- Tropical Storm Allison and the floods it caused, the Andrea Yates murders and trial. What made it worse was that all these outsiders had come in to gawk and had not helped at all. And it was then, while the reporters were standing around, that the most embarrassing thing happened.
docs.abstract: Randall Patteson profile of Houston in wake of series of setbacks: Tripical Storm Allison and flooding it caused, Andrea Yates murders and trial and, most embarrassingly, collapse of Enron Corp; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Though California state officials crowed over the Enron memos released this week outlining questionable strategies for wringing profits from the electricity market here, state lawyers said that the documents would probably have only a modest and indirect effect on their efforts to win refunds from the power generators. Ever since power prices rocketed out of control in 2000 and then especially early last year, California has struggled both to obtain federal help in capping prices and to force the generators to return what the state has said are billions of dollars of overcharges.
docs.abstract: California lawyers say that Enron Corp memos released this week outlining questionable strategies for wringing profits from electricity market in California will probably have only modest and indirect effect on their efforts to win refunds from power generators (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron, has a reason to sleep better at night, even if it means he has fewer places to sleep. Mr. Lay and his wife, Linda, who say their wealth has dwindled since Enron filed for bankruptcy in December, have so far been successful in selling the family's real estate in Aspen, Colo., to help pay their legal bills. Last week, Mr. Lay, 59, sold the third of their four Aspen properties -- a 4,537-square-foot, five-bedroom log and stone house in the Oklahoma Flats neighborhood.

Politicians recognize that the estimated $1.2 billion in retirement money lost by Enron employees has frightened many of the 42 million Americans with 401(k) plans, and are competing to propose measures to protect the nearly $2 trillion in those plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is at least one piece of legislation that Enron's move into bankruptcy protection will stall, not accelerate: the bankruptcy reform bill that passed both houses of Congress last March. Some lawmakers are weighing whether to revise provisions that could appear anti-consumer and politically unseemly after a corporate collapse that hurt thousands of workers and investors. ''Even some of the lobbyists who supported the bill tell me that they are afraid to touch it now,'' Senator Leahy said. ''I think if we were to try to jam the bill through now, it wouldn't go anywhere because everyone would be waiting for the other shoe to fall in the Enron case.''

Max may not. Finger-pointing aside, the Enron scandal portrays accounting as an intriguing, powerful and empowering discipline. Gail Farrelly Associate Professor Rutgers University Newark

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: With more than a dozen Congressional committees and subcommittees investigating the Enron mess (front page, Jan. 25), we can expect that potential criminal defendants, their lawyers and lobbyists will now be shopping the committees for immunity in exchange for testimony. While Congressional grants of immunity do not per se bar criminal prosecutions, we know from sad experience in the Iran-contra cases that they can render prosecution exceptionally difficult and frequently unattainable.
